ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Giving form to idea, using graphic design principles to organize thoughts onto projects and workflow, practice in developing skills in design.
GD

I actually learned a whole new way of thinking about graphic design. I don't expect to be an expert in design after this, but I do have a better grasp of what good design is and the skills to achieve that or at least towards it. We did a lot of projects and iterations of the same assignment, but it really helped to see what we were doing wrong or what we were used to thinking about something that Yeju wanted us to change. I also learned to apply design in different mediums and settings.
I learned about the basics of graphic design, got a better understanding of what design is, and learned about my own creative process.
I learned to perceive and appreciate the world in a new way. I feel like I left the class with a greater ability to actively engage with design that surrounds us in everyday life.
ways to think about design and conveying information effectively

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths:
- efficient method to practice and introduce design principles 
- easy to become close knit with classmates 

Weakness:
- it was on zoom
Overall, can't give much feedback since it was virtual. Strength = Yeju. Weakness = fact that over Zoom while Yeju was giving feedback it was easy to get disengaged

Strengths of this course were the multiple repetitions of assignments to challenge our thinking and get our creative minds working to think of new ways to do things, constant feedback and critiques on our projects throughout the semester, a real world scenario of designing for a classmate, and I think it was super helpful of Yeju to ask us why we did things or chose to use a certain formal quality because we did a lot of things without really knowing why or what the necessity of that tool was. She really made us get down to the bare minimum that still accomplished our task.
Zoom made the format of the class a bit harder. However, the content of the class was really great, and I learned a lot especially from our group critiques.
Yeju is amazing, and the assignments were genuinely interesting and meaningful.
The biggest strength was the quality of critiques in class. We would get immediate feedback on our work from the professor almost every class period.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Sending out periodic emails with tasks, readings, and assignments worked well to keep the course on track. However, Canvas could have been better employed to organize and structure the course.
See above

Zoom made the class difficult in many ways, especially because the class period is so long. I felt I couldn't give enough attention to my classmates by the end of the period. I also wish we had access to printers and could see classmates in person. Ordering materials for us worked well, though.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, the knowledge you gain in this course can be applied to a huge range of activities and forms of communication. If you are interested in improving your communication and presentation skills I would highly recommend this course.
Absolutely. Yeju is a goddess among us. I was skeptical at first with the assignments (like expressing dynamic just with straight black and white lines) but it truly helped me develop my GD skills

Yes, I definitely recommend for people who want to learn more about design and the basic principles of it. I would say that this course isn't a course that teaches you software or how to use the adobe suite. It is very much starting from scratch and making things with your hands, but I don't think that that should be a turn off but it really helps you to think about your choices in composition and really gives a lot of flexibility. I also really enjoyed that we did a real world simulation of a designer/client role in which we designed for our classmates.

Yes. You need to set aside enough time to properly work on each project to get something out of the class, so I wouldn't recommend it for an easy 5th class or anything. But the class is excellent and super applicable to the rest of life, and Yeju is a great teacher who really cares about each student's growth.

Absolutely. No matter what major you are, this course will allow you to better appreciate and consider the impacts of design in our everyday lives. I learned so much about how I think, and gained so much insight by discussing other peoples work as well. I finish this course with a greater love and excitement for the meaningful struggles and potentials in design.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Using real-life tools + software tools
NA
